children.text: Indicator 1: Describe structures and properties of, and changes in, matter.
(Comprehension) Use senses to describe solid objects in terms of physical attributes.
(Knowledge) Identify water in its solid and liquid forms.
(Analysis) Categorize objects by physical attributes such as color, size, and shape.
(Comprehension) Compare objects in terms of heavier or lighter.
(Application) Predict how common materials interact with water.
(Application) Classify solids in terms of the materials they are made of and their physical properties.
(Comprehension) Describe visually observable properties of liquids and classify liquids by their physical properties.
(Application) Identify mixtures of solid substances and ways to separate them.
(Comprehension) Describe physical properties of matter using the senses (touch, smell, etc.).
(Application) Use tools to relate composition to physical properties.
(Application) Demonstrate how a different substance can be made by combining two or more substances.
(Comprehension) Describe observable physical changes and properties in matter.
(Analysis) Explain how some physical properties remain the same as the mass is changed.
(Comprehension) Differentiate between the states of matter caused by changes in temperature using water.
(Knowledge) Define matter on the basis of observable physical properties.
(Knowledge) Identify the subatomic particles that make up atoms.
(Application) Classify matter based on physical and chemical properties.
(Comprehension) Describe phase changes in matter differentiating between the particle motion in solids, liquids, and gases.
(Analysis) Classify matter as elements, compounds, or mixtures.
(Application) Use the Periodic Table to compare and contrast families of elements and to classify elements as metals, metalloids, or non-metals.
(Comprehension) Compare properties of matter resulting from physical and chemical changes.
Core HS Standards
(Analysis) Use the Periodic Table to determine the atomic structure of elements, valence number, family relationships, and regions (metals, nonmetals, and metalloids).
(Comprehension) Describe ways that atoms combine.
(Application) Predict whether reactions will speed up or slow down as conditions change.
(Application) Balance chemical equations by applying the Law of Conservation of Matter.
(Comprehension) Distinguish among chemical, physical, and nuclear changes.
Advanced HS Standards
(Analysis) Distinguish between the changing models of the atom using the historical experimental evidence.
(Synthesis) Predict electron configuration, ion formation, reactivity, compound formation, periodic trends, and types of compounds formed based on location on the Periodic Table.
(Synthesis) Identify five basic types of chemical reactions and predict the products.
(Synthesis) Describe factors that affect solution interactions.
(Application) Examine energy transfer as matter changes.
(Application) Perform stoichiometric calculations.
(Application) Apply the kinetic molecular theory to solve quantitative problems involving pressure, volume, temperature, and number of moles of gas.
(Synthesis) Use models to make predictions about molecular structure, chemical bonds, chemical reactivity, and polarity of molecules.
(Analysis) Describe the characteristics of equilibria.
Indicator 2: Analyze forces, their forms, and their effects on motions.
(Comprehension) Describe relative positions of objects.
(Application) Demonstrate how moving objects exhibit different types of motion.
(Application) Predict the effects of magnets on other magnets and other objects.
(Application) Demonstrate how forces act over a distance.
(Knowledge) Identify forces in specific situations that require objects to interact, change directions, or stop.
(Analysis) Analyze the structure and design of simple and compound machines to determine how the machines make work easier by trading force for distance.
(Comprehension) Describe how push/pull forces acting on an object produce motion.
Core HS Standards
(Analysis) Apply concepts of distance and time to the quantitative relationships of motion using appropriate mathematical formulas, equations, and units.
(Application) Predict motion of an object using Newton's Laws.
(Application) Relate concepts of force, distance, and time to the quantitative relationships of work, energy, and power.
Advanced HS Standards
(Synthesis) Solve vector problems graphically and analytically.
(Analysis) Relate gravitational or centripetal force to projectile or uniform circular motion.
Indicator 3: Analyze interactions of energy and matter.
(Comprehension) Compare sounds in terms of high pitch, low pitch, loud and soft (volume).
(Knowledge) Define energy and differentiate between sources of renewable and non-renewable energy.
(Application) Demonstrate how sound consists of vibrations and pitch.
(Knowledge) Identify how sound is used as a means of communication.
(Knowledge) Identify materials as being conductors or insulators of electricity.
(Application) Construct and define a simple circuit.
(Application) Use magnets, electromagnets, magnetic fields, and compasses to explore magnetic energy.
(Application) Demonstrate and explain how to measure heat flow into an object.
(Comprehension) Describe the Sun's ability to produce energy in the forms of light and heat.
(Comprehension) Describe basic properties of light.
(Comprehension) Identify types of energy transformations.
Core HS Standards
(Application) Describe the relationships among potential energy, kinetic energy, and work as applied to the Law of Conservation of Energy.
(Comprehension) Describe how characteristics of waves are related to one another.
(Application) Describe electrical effects in terms of motion and concentrations of charged particles.
Advanced HS Standards
(Synthesis) Explain wave behavior in the fundamental processes of reflection, refraction, diffraction, interference, resonance, and image formation.
(Application) Describe the relationship between charged particles, static electricity, and electric fields.
(Analysis) Describe the relationship between changing magnetic and electric fields.
Indicator 1: Understand the fundamental structures, functions, classifications, and mechanisms found in living things.
(Application) Sort living from non-living things.
(Application) Discover life needs of green plants.
(Knowledge) Identify the parts of a plant.
(Knowledge) List life needs of people and other animals.
(Application) Classify plants according to similarities and differences.
(Application) Classify people and animals according to similarities and differences.
(Knowledge) Identify the basic structures, functions, and needs of plants in relation to their environment.
(Knowledge) Identify characteristic features of animals and their related functions in relation to their environment.
(Comprehension) Describe life cycles, including growth and metamorphosis, of familiar organisms.
(Knowledge) Identify the basic systems (digestive, skeletal, muscular, nervous, respiratory, and circulatory) and major organs.
(Comprehension) Differentiate between vertebrates and invertebrates, and classify the five groups of vertebrates (mammal, reptile, amphibian, bird, and fish) based on characteristics.
(Comprehension) Describe the basic process of photosynthesis and the role of light as a source of energy in plants.
(Comprehension) Illustrate the difference between plant and animal cells.
(Comprehension) Explain the importance and scientific use of a classification system.
(Knowledge) Identify basic cell organelles and their functions.
(Comprehension) Identify and explain the function of the human systems and the organs within each system.
(Application) Classify organisms by using the currently recognized kingdoms.
(Comprehension) Describe and identify the structure of vascular and non-vascular plants.
Core HS Standards
(Analysis) Relate cellular functions and processes to specialized structures within cells.
(Application) Classify organisms using characteristics and evolutionary relationship of major taxa.
(Analysis) Identify structures and function relationships within major taxa.
Advanced HS Standards
(Synthesis) Explain the physical and chemical processes of photosynthesis and cell respiration and their importance to plant and animal life.
(Synthesis) Describe how living systems use biofeedback mechanisms to maintain homeostasis.
(Synthesis) Explain how gene expression regulates cell growth and differentiation.
(Application) Identify factors that change the rates of enzyme catalyzed reactions.
(Analysis) Classify organisms using characteristics and evolutionary relationships of domains.
Indicator 2: Analyze various patterns of inheritance and biological change.
(Comprehension) Describe physical similarities and differences between parents and offspring.
(Comprehension) Describe how flowering plants go through a series of orderly changes in their life cycle.
(Comprehension) Compare life cycles of various living things.
(Analysis) Explain how animals instinctively meet basic needs in their environment.
(Knowledge) Identify behavioral and structural adaptations that allow a plant or animal to survive in a particular environment.
(Analysis) Explain how a size of a population is dependent upon the available resources within its community.
(Evaluation) Predict physical characteristics with family lineage.
(Comprehension) Describe structures and processes involved in plant reproduction.
(Comprehension) Distinguish between processes involved in sexual and asexual reproduction.
Core HS Standards
(Application) Predict inheritance patterns using a single allele.
(Synthesis) Describe how genetic recombination, mutations, and natural selection lead to adaptations, evolution, extinction, or the emergence of new species.
Advanced HS Standards
(Synthesis) Predict the results of complex inheritance patterns involving multiple alleles and genes.
Indicator 3: Analyze how organisms are linked to one another and the environment.
(Application) Relate characteristics of plants and animals that allow them to live in specific habitats.
(Comprehension) Describe ways that plants and animals depend on each other.
(Comprehension) Associate adaptations in plants and animals in response to seasonal changes.
(Knowledge) Recognize what it means for a species to be extinct or endangered.
(Comprehension) Describe how species depend on one another and on the environment for survival.
(Comprehension) Explain how environments support a diversity of plants and animals.
(Comprehension) Describe ways humans impact air, water, and habitat quality.
(Application) Examine fossils and describe how they provide evidence of change in organisms.
(Comprehension) Describe the flow of energy through food chains and webs.
(Comprehension) Describe how natural events and/or human influences may help or harm ecosystems.
(Application) Using an energy pyramid model, analyze the roles of organisms to determine the transfer of energy.
(Comprehension) Describe how interrelationships enable some organisms to survive.
(Application) Predict the effects of biotic and abiotic factors on a species' survival.
Core HS Standards
(Comprehension) Identify factors that can cause changes in stability of populations, communities, and ecosystems.
Advanced HS Standards
(Synthesis) Relate genetic, instinct, and behavior patterns to biodiversity and survival of species.
Indicator 1: Analyze the various structures and processes of the Earth system.
(Comprehension) Describe simple Earth patterns in daily life.
(Comprehension) Recognize changes in weather over time.
(Comprehension) Describe rocks in terms of properties.
(Comprehension) Describe types and patterns of weather during different seasons.
(Knowledge) Identify and locate geological features using maps and globes.
(Comprehension) Recognize and distinguish between forms of water in the Earth system.
(Knowledge) Define the difference between a rock and a mineral.
(Comprehension) Describe how humans use Earth's natural resources.
(Comprehension) Describe the basic stages of the water cycle.
(Comprehension) Describe how weather conditions and phenomena occur and can be predicted.
(Comprehension) Describe the basic structure of Earth's interior.
(Comprehension) Describe how the spheres (lithosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, and biosphere) of the Earth interact.
(Application) Examine the role of water on the Earth.
(Comprehension) Explain processes involved in the formation of the Earth's structure.
(Application) Identify and classify minerals and rocks.
(Analysis) Explain the role of plate tectonics in shaping Earth.
(Analysis) Explain the factors that create weather and the instruments and technologies that assess it.
(Application) Examine the chemical and physical properties of the ocean to determine causes and effects of currents and waves.
(Analysis) Explain the impact of weathering and erosion on the Earth.
Core HS Standards
(Comprehension) Explain how elements and compounds cycle between living and non-living systems.
(Application) Describe how atmospheric chemistry may affect global climate.
(Analysis) Assess how human activity has changed the land, ocean, and atmosphere of Earth.
Advanced HS Standards
(Application) Explain how elements and compounds cycle between living and non-living systems.
(Analysis) Compare, quantitatively and qualitatively, methods used to determine geological time.
Indicator 2: Analyze essential principles and ideas about the composition and structure of the universe.
(Knowledge) Identify the Earth as one of the planets that orbit the Sun.
(Analysis) Recognize changes in the appearance of the Moon over time.
(Comprehension) Describe the motions of Earth, Sun, and Moon.
(Comprehension) Describe the components (Sun, planets and moons) of the solar system.
(Comprehension) Explain how the Earth's rotation affects the appearance of the sky.
(Knowledge) Identify the organization and relative scale of the solar system.
(Analysis) Compare celestial bodies within the solar system using composition, size, and orbital motion.
(Analysis) Differentiate the influences of the relative positions of the Earth, Moon, and Sun.
Core HS Standards
(Comprehension) Recognize how Newtonian mechanics can be applied to the study of the motions of the solar system.
Advanced HS Standards
(Analysis) Describe the evidence supporting the Big Bang theory.
(Analysis) Describe the physical and nuclear dynamics involved in the formation, evolution, and death of a star.
(Application) Describe various ways data about the universe is collected.
Indicator 1: Analyze various implications/effects of scientific advancement within the environment and society.
(Analysis) Recognize ways to recycle, reuse, and reduce consumption of natural resources.
(Comprehension) Describe how people continue to invent new ways of doing things, solving problems, and getting work done.
(Comprehension) Explain how new ideas and inventions often affect people.
(Knowledge) Identify scientific changes that have affected transportation, health, sanitation, and communication.
(Comprehension) Describe how designing a solution may have constraints.
(Comprehension) Describe how science and technology have helped society to solve problems.
(Comprehension) Describe how science and technology are used to solve problems in different professions and businesses.
(Comprehension) Describe how science and technology have been influenced by social needs, attitudes, and values.
Core HS Standards
(Application) Explain ethical roles and responsibilities of scientists and scientific research.
(Evaluation) Evaluate and describe the impact of scientific discoveries on historical events and social, economic, and ethical issues.
Indicator 2: Analyze the relationships/interactions among science, technology, environment, and society.
(Evaluation) Explain the interrelationship of populations, resources, and environments.
(Knowledge) Given a scenario, identify the problem(s) of human activity on the local, regional, or global environment.
(Application) Given a scenario, predict the consequence(s) of human activity on the local, regional, or global environment.
(Synthesis) Given a scenario, offer solutions to problems created by human activity on the local, regional, or global environment.
Core HS Standards
(Evaluation) Describe immediate and long-term consequences of potential solutions for technological issues.
(Analysis) Analyze factors that could limit technological des
(Synthesis) Analyze and describe the benefits, limitations, cost, and consequences involved in using, conserving, or recycling resources.
Indicator 1: Understand the nature and origin of scientific knowledge.
(Comprehension) Differentiate among facts, predictions, theory, and laws/principles in scientific investigations.
Core HS Standards
(Evaluation) Evaluate a scientific discovery to determine and describe how societal, cultural, and personal beliefs influence scientific investigations and interpretations.
(Synthesis) Describe the role of observation and evidence in the development and modification of hypotheses, theories, and laws.
Indicator 2: Apply the skills necessary to conduct scientific investigations.
(Application) Pose questions that can be explored through scientific investigations.
(Application) Conduct scientific investigations using given procedures.
(Synthesis) Design a replicable scientific investigation.
Core HS Standards
(Synthesis) Apply science process skills to design and conduct student investigations.
(Application) Practice safe and effective laboratory techniques.
Advanced HS Standards
(Synthesis) Manipulate multiple variables with repeated trials.
(Evaluation) Use statistical analysis of data to evaluate the validity of results.
(Analysis) Demonstrate correct precision in measurements and calculations.
